intro: Plagiobothrys scouleri subsp. penicillatus, commonly known as the Penicillate bladderpod, is a flowering plant native to the Pacific Northwest of North America. It belongs to the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its small, showy flowers that typically bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant has slender, hairy stems and pinnately compound leaves, with small, oval-shaped leaflets. It is often found in moist, open habitats such as meadows and streambanks, and is known for its unique seed pods that resemble tiny penicils, giving it its common name.
